entries.author: breno_de_oliveira
entries.text: When people use the keys() function on hashes, they quickly notice that the result is always the same. It takes a lot of energy to tell them they cannot rely on this order. With the recent changes in perl this will be much more obvious, making it easier to teach. This will also break the code of all those people who rely on the order despite what the documentation says. Breno G. de Oliveira explains it clearly and even show how the order that keys() returns changes even in current versions of Perl.
entries.title: Are you relying on hash keys being ordered?

entries.text: One of the biggest problem I encounter when starting to clean up legacy code, is locating and eliminating duplicate code.
